marketNews.title: Revision of DHE SDA: 100% Allocation for 1 Year
marketNews.content: Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto said on Tuesday (21/1) that the government will revise the foreign exchange placement rule for export proceeds of natural resources (DHE SDA) to 100% for a period of one year. The proportion and tenor of the placement are larger and longer than the existing rule, which required a minimum of 30% for three months. The revision will take effect on 1 March 2025 for exporters of natural resources with export values of at least USD 250,000. The revision is currently being harmonised and will be issued soon. Airlangga claimed that the government will provide many incentives for the mineral, coal and other natural resource sectors, except for the oil and gas sector. The incentives include: - A 0% income tax rate on interest income from DHE SDA placement instruments. - Exporters can use the DHE SDA placement instrument as collateral for back‑to‑back rupiah credit from banks or Investment Management Institutions (LPI) for domestic rupiah needs. - Exporters can use a swap instrument with a bank if they need rupiah for their business activities. - Funding guaranteed by collateral – including cash collateral, giro accounts or savings deposits that meet certain requirements – will be exempt from the maximum credit provision limit (BMPK), so funding that uses the DHE SDA placement as collateral will not affect the gearing ratio against equity. - DHE SDA can be converted into rupiah and will be counted as a reduction of the placement obligation percentage. - Foreign exchange instruments can be used to pay state levies such as taxes, royalties and dividends. The revision aims to increase the supply of foreign exchange in the country to ease pressure on the rupiah. On Tuesday (21/1) the rupiah had fallen 0.9% month‑on‑month to a level of 16,335 per US dollar. Airlangga claimed that the revision could increase the country's foreign exchange by up to USD 90 billion, equivalent to 58% of the 2024 realization of USD 156 billion. However, the revision was criticised by exporters. Before Airlangga announced the change, the Chairman of the Indonesian Exporters Association, Benny Soetrisno, said on Monday (20/1) that the revision would disrupt exporters' finances because export proceeds would have to be placed domestically while financing has traditionally come from foreign financial institutions. To ease the burden, Airlangga said last week that the term‑deposit yield on DHE SDA placement would be higher than Singapore's, ranging between 4.12% and 4.48%, though he did not provide further details. Last week, Bank Indonesia Governor Perry Warjiyo also said that Bank Indonesia is preparing SUVBI and SVBI as additional instruments for DHE SDA placement, in addition to existing instruments such as foreign‑exchange term deposits and FX swaps. Key Takeaway: In brief, the DHE SDA placement revision could provide a positive sentiment for banking issuers as foreign exchange liquidity increases, while there is operational working‑capital liquidity risk for exporters lacking strong cash balance sheets. Further clarity and detail on the incentives are still needed to assess the impact on exporters.

marketNews.title: Parent Company JPFA, Japfa Ltd., Under Discussion of Share Transaction
marketNews.content: - $JPFA: The board of Japfa Ltd. (SGX: JAP), the parent of Japfa Comfeed Indonesia, announced that it is currently in further discussions regarding a possible share transaction of Japfa Ltd., without providing further details. Previously, Bloomberg reported in March 2024 that the owners of Japfa Ltd. were considering taking the company private. The board stated that no decision has been made and there is no guarantee that a transaction will occur. For the first nine months of 2024, JPFA contributed 76% of Japfa Ltd.'s total revenue, which reached USD 3.4 billion. - $CBDK: Bangun Kosambi Sukses announced a plan to acquire PT Industri Pameran Nusantara from an affiliate by issuing 135 million new shares valued at IDR 2.3 trillion. The transaction is part of the use of IPO proceeds. After the transaction, CBDK's ownership in PT Industri Pameran Nusantara will increase from zero to 99.99%. The funds obtained by PT Industri Pameran Nusantara will be used to finance the construction of meeting, incentive, conference and exhibition (MICE) facilities. - $GOTO: Head of Corporate Affairs GoTo Financial, Audrey P. Petriny, told Bisnis that the company targets consumer loan disbursement of IDR 8.6 trillion in 2025, double the realization of IDR 4.3 trillion in the first nine months of 2024. - $DNET: Indoritel Makmur Internasional, through its subsidiary PT Mega Akses Persada, signed a credit facility of up to IDR 5.9 trillion from Bank Mandiri (BMRI) and Bank Syariah Indonesia (BRIS). The facility, with a 13‑year term, is intended for refinancing fiber‑optic network equipment and capital expenditures for 2025‑2027. It carries a fixed interest rate of 7.5% per annum and a floating rate based on the BI Rate plus a minimum margin of 1%. - $HEAL: Medikaloka Hermina director Tan Suryanti Gunadi purchased 124,000 HEAL shares at an average price of IDR 1,595 per share on 17 January 2025. The total transaction value was approximately IDR 198 million. After the transaction, Tan Suryanti Gunadi's ownership in HEAL increased from 0.0286% to 0.0294%. - $IPCC: Indonesia Terminal Services recorded cargo handling of 1,057,831 units in 2024, a 15% year‑on‑year increase, and ship visits to its terminals rose to 2,978, up 42% YoY. The company also reported a 7.49% YoY increase in handling of completely built‑up (CBU) imported cars to 856,870 units in 2024, and truck or bus cargo handling rose to 174,609 units, up 69.21% YoY. - $MYOH: Samindo Resources secretary Ahmad Zaki said the company targets overburden removal volume of 35 million cubic meters in 2025 (versus 30.7 million in 2024) and coal production of 6 million tonnes (versus 5.4 million in 2024). The increase is based on strong demand from China and Southeast Asian countries and domestic power and smelter needs. MYOH allocated USD 13 million capex for 2025, aimed at optimizing operational units and more sustainable spare‑part management. - Donald Trump was inaugurated as President of the United States on Monday (20/1). In his inauguration, Trump announced several policy proposals, including opening more areas for oil and gas exploration, imposing a 25% import tariff on Canada and Mexico effective 1 February 2025, delaying tariffs on China, ending electric‑vehicle subsidies, ending the TikTok ban in the US, and withdrawing the US from the 2015 Paris Agreement and the WHO. - The head of the Aceh Oil and Gas Management Agency, Nasri Djalal, said that Kuwait Foreign Petroleum Exploration Company (KUFPEC) plans to invest USD 10 billion in oil and gas exploration and development in Aceh. Country Manager Sara Al‑Baker said KUFPEC is evaluating investment opportunities in Indonesia and previously indicated interest in the Natuna D‑Alpha gas block and future government oil block offerings. - Analysts surveyed by Reuters expect crude palm oil (CPO) futures prices to rise 5.4% year‑on‑year in 2025 to RM 4,350 per tonne, driven by the implementation of the B40 biodiesel mandate in Indonesia, which will reduce exports. The Malaysian Palm Oil Association CEO estimates the mandate will absorb an additional 1.2‑1.7 million tonnes of Indonesian CPO. Consensus forecasts Indonesian CPO production to increase 1.9% YoY in 2025 to 49.8 million tonnes. Malaysia is expected to produce 19.5 million tonnes in 2025, a 0.83% YoY increase, affected by bad weather, labor shortages and low replanting rates. - BYD Motor Indonesia's CEO Eagle Zhou said the company aims to complete its Indonesia plant by the end of 2025. The plant, valued at USD 1 billion and located in the Subang Smartpolitan industrial zone owned by Surya Semesta Internusa (SSIA), will have an annual production capacity of 150,000 electric vehicles and is intended to serve the export market in the long term. BYD recorded wholesale sales of 15,429 units by the end of 2024, representing 35.7% of the total battery electric vehicle market share in Indonesia for 2024. - Mitrabahtera Segara Sejati (MBSS) announced the sale of one floating crane barge owned by its subsidiary PT Mitra Galley Segara Sejati to a non‑affiliate party. The transaction value was approximately USD 4.3 million or about IDR 70 billion. - Logisticsplus International (LOPI) director Wahyu Dwi Jatmiko sold 25.5 million LOPI shares at an average price of IDR 63 per share on 13 January 2025, totaling about IDR 1.6 billion for investment strategy purposes. After the transaction, Wahyu Dwi Jatmiko's ownership in LOPI decreased from 39.3% to 37%.

tickerNews.title: CBDK: Plan to Acquire PT Industri Pameran Nusantara
tickerNews.content: Bangun Kosambi Sukses announced a plan to acquire PT Industri Pameran Nusantara from an affiliate by issuing 135 million new shares valued at IDR 2.3 trillion. The transaction is part of the use of IPO proceeds. After the transaction, CBDK's ownership in PT Industri Pameran Nusantara will increase from zero to 99.99%. The funds obtained by PT Industri Pameran Nusantara will be used to finance the construction of meeting, incentive, conference and exhibition (MICE) facilities.

tickerNews.title: GOTO: Target Consumer Loan Disbursement of IDR 8.6 Trillion in 2025
tickerNews.content: Head of Corporate Affairs GoTo Financial, Audrey P. Petriny, told Bisnis that the company targets consumer loan disbursement of IDR 8.6 trillion in 2025, double the realization of IDR 4.3 trillion in the first nine months of 2024.

tickerNews.title: DNET: Indoritel Secures IDR 5.9 Trillion Credit Facility
tickerNews.content: Indoritel Makmur Internasional, through its subsidiary PT Mega Akses Persada, signed a credit facility of up to IDR 5.9 trillion from Bank Mandiri (BMRI) and Bank Syariah Indonesia (BRIS). The facility, with a 13‑year term, is intended for refinancing fiber‑optic network equipment and capital expenditures for 2025‑2027. It carries a fixed interest rate of 7.5% per annum and a floating rate based on the BI Rate plus a minimum margin of 1%.

tickerNews.content: Medikaloka Hermina director Tan Suryanti Gunadi purchased 124,000 HEAL shares at an average price of IDR 1,595 per share on 17 January 2025. The total transaction value was approximately IDR 198 million. After the transaction, Tan Suryanti Gunadi's ownership in HEAL increased from 0.0286% to 0.0294%.

tickerNews.title: IPCC: Cargo Handling Increases in 2024
tickerNews.content: Indonesia Terminal Services recorded cargo handling of 1,057,831 units in 2024, a 15% year‑on‑year increase, and ship visits to its terminals rose to 2,978, up 42% YoY. The company also reported a 7.49% YoY increase in handling of completely built‑up (CBU) imported cars to 856,870 units in 2024, and truck or bus cargo handling rose to 174,609 units, up 69.21% YoY.

tickerNews.title: MYOH: Targets 35 Million Cubic Meters Overburden Removal in 2025
tickerNews.content: Samindo Resources secretary Ahmad Zaki said the company targets overburden removal volume of 35 million cubic meters in 2025 (versus 30.7 million in 2024) and coal production of 6 million tonnes (versus 5.4 million in 2024). The increase is based on strong demand from China and Southeast Asian countries and domestic power and smelter needs. MYOH allocated USD 13 million capex for 2025, aimed at optimizing operational units and more sustainable spare‑part management.
